Requests for permission for commercial publication or other use should be emailed to the project team.

div1.p: Sir, In my communication dated at Washington on the 20th ull I informed you that so soon as the necessary documents (then on their way from Boston) came to hand, the explanation called for by your letters of the 19th, in relation to the refusal of the USS Yorktown to salute the French Fort Aumale should be furnished; these papers having been received, I am enabled to collect from the report of Commander Bell, and the correspondance which took place on the occasion the following particulars: It appears that on the 14th day of Novr 1845, that officer entered the river Gaboon (Africa) with the USS Yorktown under his command; in proceding up the river he passed a small blockhause erected on the bank by the French. At 3"30' P.M. he anchored the ship off King Glass town, 4 miles above said block hause. At 8 A.M the following day an officer came on board

from the French brick of mar "Malouine" with the commander's compliments, at the same time he handed Commandant Bell a note. On the officer's retiring he opended it was from the commanding officer of the blockhause expressing surprise that he, Commander Bell, should have passed the fort without saluting, and then officially demanded a salute to the French flag. Commander Bell took no notice of the peremptory demand. He sent an officer on board the "Malouine" to return the usual civilities, at the same time regressed the commander to take charge of a letter directed to the commanding officer of the French forces on the station, to which he readily assented. The next day Commander Bell sent the letter on board, the Commander of the "Malouine" refused to receive it, unless Commander Bell saluted or made a suitable explanation. This his determination he conveyed to Comm. Bell in writing. Both
with the "" In that it my duty to the constant of the commander account of the affaire to the Department at the time.
div1.ab: The George Secretary of the Navy. Washington
